title: 112_hr6654
content: The Act may be cited as the "Foreign Counterfeit Merchandise Prevention Act" and involves the exchange of information related to trade enforcement. The "Foreign Counterfeit Merchandise Prevention Act" amends Section 1905 of title 18, United States Code, allowing U.S. Customs and Border Protection officers to provide information on merchandise to copyright or trademark owners without violating the law. This includes details, samples, and digital images of the merchandise presented for examination. The "Foreign Counterfeit Merchandise Prevention Act" allows U.S. Customs and Border Protection officers to provide information on seized merchandise to copyright or trademark owners, including details like date of importation and port of entry. The "Foreign Counterfeit Merchandise Prevention Act" requires U.S. Customs and Border Protection to provide details of seized merchandise to trademark owners, including date of importation, port of entry, description, quantity, country of origin, manufacturer, exporter, importer, and images. Definitions include terms like 'registered mark' and 'counterfeit mark' as per the Lanham Act. The term 'without redaction' means not altering or hiding any information on merchandise or its packaging. This rule applies to tangible goods presented to U.S. Customs and Border Protection for import or export. SEC. 3. PREVENTION OF IMPORTATION OF MANUFACTURED GOODS BEARING INFRINGING MARKS. SEC. 3 of the Lanham Act is amended to include provisions for the detention of critical merchandise suspected of bearing a counterfeit mark by U.S. Customs and Border Protection. The Secretary is required to provide the owner of the registered trademark with information and images of the detained merchandise. The Lanham Act is amended to allow U.S. Customs and Border Protection to detain critical merchandise suspected of counterfeit marks. The owner of the trademark can receive information and images of the detained merchandise, and samples can be provided without redaction. Critical merchandise includes various items such as aircraft engines, children's sleepwear, cosmetics, drugs, and food. The Lanham Act allows U.S. Customs and Border Protection to detain merchandise suspected of counterfeit marks, including items like aircraft engines, children's sleepwear, cosmetics, drugs, and food. Additionally, certain items such as pesticide chemicals, semiconductors, tobacco products, and others listed on the United States Munitions List may also be detained if they pose a danger to consumers' health, safety, welfare, or national security.
